moves.3. Nf3 g5 4. Nc3 Bg7 5. Bc4:
we arrived to an old position in king's gambit accepted. 
h4 is often played. 
this position is not played nowadays as it gives poor chances for black to win, even to draw
moves.5... g4: d6 is more careful. From now, i was expecting a bad cyclone on my head !
moves.6. O-O: a good move ! white sacrifies a piece to open the f column and gain time.
moves.6... gxf3: let's go !  I want to loose with my stomach full of white knight !
moves.7. Qxf3: the f4 pawn will now pay for Knight's death.
moves.8. Qxf4:
... it seems that white did not analyzed the situation correctly: 
the sacrifice Bxf7 was giving surely a winning attack :
Bxf7, Kxf7, Qh5 , Kf8, Rxf4 , Nf6, Nd5, Nd7, b4 etc.
moves.8... Bd4+: after a long analyze, i found  this move that makes me live for some time more...
moves.9. Kh1 Qf6: here it is, black are ready to sign for a queen exchange as they have two points advance.
moves.10. Nd5:
white looks to c7, but let black exchange queens
i was expecting Qg3
moves.10... Qxf4:
black takes a breath 
white cannot take c7 immediatly ? : Nxc7 , Kd7, Nxa8,  Qxf1, Bxf1 etc.
moves.11. Rxf4 Bb6: just in time to defend c7
moves.12. Nxb6: here white are not obliged to take immediatly. i think Rxf7 was better
moves.12... axb6 13. Bxf7+:
black are loosing a pawn again, but escaped from the 1st white storm. 
at that time, i sweared never accept again a king's gambit !
moves.13... Kd8: Ke7 was better to control f6, f7 and f8
moves.14. d3:
now is a series of white imprecisions.
white have still a development advance. their plan would be d4, a3, Bd2 or e3 and Rf1
moves.14... Ne7: black have a lot of work to develop.  black king must find rapidly a square to be secured.
moves.15. Be3 c5: black plan is to give the c7 square to their king, d7 to the bishop and c6 to the "b" Knight, and to finally coordinate rooks
moves.16. d4: an error. white 2nd attack is not prepared. white needed to play a3 to put a second rook in action.
moves.17. dxc5:
taking c5 isolates pawn e4 and let black to take with b6, it also gives the e5 square to black. 
protecting the pawn with c3 was better.
moves.17... bxc5 18. a3: finally open the liberty door to Ra1.
moves.18... Kc7 19. Bd5: a strange move. why did the white want to exchange an active piece and give the pair of bishop ? Raf1 was definitly more frightening
moves.19... Nxd5 20. exd5 Ne5: the black knight is now the chessboard's more powerful piece. it prevents c4, Rf7.
moves.21. h3: a passive move. i was expecing Rf1. this gives the chance to black to achieve their development
moves.22. b3:
a bad move. 
Rf1 was better
moves.22... b5:
for the first time of the game, i have the initiative.
the rook a1 never moved !!
moves.24... Ref8: black want to enter in a winning final
moves.25. Rxf8 Rxf8 26. a4: white have a passed a pawn
moves.26... bxa4 27. bxa4: the white pawn structure is now ruins
moves.27... Ra8 28. a5: with this move, the d5 pawn is now not defendable
moves.28... Bb5 29. Bf2 Bc4 30. Bg3: a good plan for black, but too late
moves.30... Bxd5 31. Bxe5 dxe5: black have a decisive advantage with one piece more.
moves.32. Ra4: yes :-) !!! the rook is waking up and is hungry
moves.32... e4 33. g4 e3 34. Kg1 Kc6 35. c4:
the c4 pawn is now a target for the Black bishop
black have a winning final.
moves.35... Bf7 36. Kf1 Kd6 37. Ke2 Re8 38. a6: it was my birthday, i was 44 !
